Award.AwardTitle: NCRN-MN: Improving the Interpretability and Usability of the American Community Survey Through Hierarchical Multiscale Spatio-Temporal Statistical Models

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
The American Community Survey (ACS) is an ongoing survey that releases data annually, providing communities with the timely information needed to plan the distribution of resources and services. According to the U.S. Census Bureau, the data from the survey provides input into how more than $400 billion in federal and state funds are distributed annually. Census released the first five-year period estimates associated with the ACS for all standard tabulation areas in 2010. This marks an interesting time in U.S. history as Census shifts from the decennial census long-form data to using an ongoing survey that releases data annually. Making this transition presents many methodological challenges, both for Census and for data users. The hierarchical multiscale spatio-temporal statistical models and expansive statistical methodology in this project will address many of these challenges and facilitate broader and more effective utilization of the ACS. In particular, this project will develop an efficient framework for carrying out small area estimation while preserving geographical and temporal constraints that arise from the aggregate structure found in the ACS. Further, by borrowing strength across multiple scales in space and time and multiple outcomes, the approach will reduce the variance in the ACS small area estimates and its derivatives. Additionally, from a data-user perspective, the methodology will simultaneously provide coherent estimates on several temporal scales rather than being hampered by the published multiyear estimates, allowing researchers to compare trends across different geographic scales and units.

This project will investigate methodology that provides novel solutions across a wide-range of applied problems. The research will improve the interpretability and usability of the ACS through the development of hierarchical multiscale spatio-temporal statistical models. In addition, the project will provide a variety of methods that are of independent interest and can be used in many other surveys administered by Census and other federal statistics agencies. Several of the proposed methods also will directly carry over to the area of disease mapping and thus provide important tools for public health. The project will contribute to the statistics literature and will be of value to the work of government agencies and many subject-matter disciplines. One of the major focuses of this project will be to educate and train graduate students and postdoctoral researchers. It is expected that students will acquire the requisite skills for possible integration into the federal sector. This activity is supported by the NSF-Census Research Network funding opportunity.

POR.DRECONTENT:
1. We developed flexible univariate models for spatial and spatio-temporal area-level modeling of the American Community Survey (ACS) and other data products. Specifically, we considered dimension reduction, flexible distributional assumptions, and social media data.

  • Sengupta, A. and Cressie, N., (2013) Empirical Hierarchical Modelling for Count Data using the Spatial Random Effects Model. Spatial Economic Analysis, 8, 389-418.
  • Porter, A.T., Holan, S.H., Wikle, C.K., and Cressie, N. (2014) Spatial Fay-Herriot Models for Small Area Estimation with Functional Covariates. Spatial Statistics. 10, 27 – 42.
  • Porter, A.T., Holan, S.H., and Wikle, C.K. (2015) Bayesian Semiparametric Hierarchical Empirical Likelihood Spatial Models. Journal of Statistical Planning and Inference, 165: 78– 90.
  • Burden, S., Cressie, N., and Steel, D.G. (2015) The SAR Model for Very Large Datasets: A Reduced Rank Approach. Econometrics. 3, 317 – 338.

2. We introduced flexible multivariate spatial and spatio-temporal models and associated distribution theory and dimension reduction for efficient modeling of area-level data. The proposed methods produced estimates from millions of observations simultaneously that result in superior precision.

  • Bradley, J.R., Holan, S.H., and Wikle, C.K. (2019) Bayesian Hierarchical Models with Conjugate Full-Conditional Distributions for Dependent Data from the Natural Exponential Family. (To Appear – Journal of the American Statistical Association – T&M).
  • Bradley, , J.R., Wikle, C.K., and Holan, S.H. (2019) Spatio-Temporal Models for Big Multinomial Data using the Conditional Multivariate Logit-Beta Distribution, Journal of Time Series Analysis, 40: 363–382.
  • Bradley, J.R., Holan, S.H., and Wikle, C.K. (2018) Computationally Efficient Multivariate Spatio-Temporal Models for High-Dimensional Count-Valued Data. Bayesian Analysis, 13, 253–281.
  • Cressie, N. and Zammit-Mangion, A. (2016) Multivariate Spatial Covariance Models: A Conditional Approach. Biometrika, 103(4), 915-935.
  • Bradley, J.R., Holan, S.H., and Wikle, C.K. (2015) Multivariate Spatio-Temporal Models for High-Dimensional Areal Data with Application to Longitudinal Employer-Household Dynamics. Annals of Applied Statistics, 9: 1761–1791.

3. We tackled the multiscale spatial and change of spatial support issues that are common to many official statistics data products. The research allows data-users to define their own spatial and/or temporal support. Notably, the proposed methods handle a broad range of problems including joint spatio-temporal change of support, change of spatial support for count-valued data, and regionalization.

  • Bradley, J.R., Wikle, C.K., and Holan, S.H. (2015) Spatio-Temporal Change of Support with Application to American Community Survey Multi-Year Period Estimates, Stat, 4: 255–270.
  • Bradley, J.R., Wikle, C.K., and Holan, S.H. (2016) Bayesian Spatial Change of Support for Count-Valued Survey Data with Application to the American Community Survey. Journal of the American Statistical Association, 111: 472–487.
  • Bradley, J.R., Wikle, C.K., and Holan, S.H. (2017) Regionalization of Multiscale Spatial Processes using a Criterion for Spatial Aggregation Error, Journal of the Royal Statistical Society – Series B, 79: 815–832.
  • Huang, H.-C., Cressie, N., Zammit-Mangion, A., and Huang, G. (2019). False Discovery Rates to Detect Signals from Incomplete Spatially Aggregated Data. arXiv

4. In conjunction with researchers at U.S. Census, two R package were produced.

  • Raim,  A.M., Holan, S.H., Bradley, J.R., and Wikle, C.K. stcos: Space-Time Change of Support, https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/stcos/index.html
  • Bertolacci, M., Zammit-Mangion, A., and Cressie, N. ABSReport2018, Disclosure avoidance software delivered to Census Bureau (2019).

5. We addressed the problem of combining data from multiple surveys and other related auxiliary data sources. This research provide tools needed to improve the precision of the tabulated estimates.

  • Bradley, J.R., Holan, S.H., and Wikle, C.K. (2016) Multivariate Spatio-Temporal Survey Fusion with Application to the American Community Survey and Local Area Unemployment Statistics, Stat, 5: 224–233.
  • Porter, A.T., Holan, S.H., Wikle, C.K., and Cressie, N. (2014) Spatial Fay-Herriot Models for Small Area Estimation with Functional Covariates. Spatial Statistics. 10, 27 – 42.

6. We developed spatial models to address the ever-present issue of data confidentiality. As concerns regarding disclosure avoidance and privacy protection are on the rise, research in spatial data confidentiality is extremely important. The importance of this is reinforced as statistical agencies have a responsibility to protect sensitive respondent information.

  • Quick, H., Holan, S.H., Wikle, C.K., and Reiter, J.P. (2015) Bayesian Marked Point Process Modeling for Generating Fully Synthetic Public Use Data with Point-Referenced Geography. Spatial Statistics, 439–451.
  • Quick, H., Holan, S.H., and Wikle, C.K. (2018) Generating Partially Synthetic Geocoded Public Use Data with Decreased Disclosure Risk Using Differential Smoothing. Journal of the Royal Statistical Society – Series A, 181(3): 649–661.

The Missouri node was part of a network of nodes that was honored with the American Statistical Association’s “Statistical Partnerships Among Academe, Industry and Government” (SPAIG Award). A full report on the network’s activities appears in the publication:

  • Weinberg, D.H., Abowd, J.A., Belli, R.F., Cressie, N., Eck, A., Folch, D.C., Holan, S.H., Levenstein, M.C., Olson, K.M., Reiter, J.P., Shapiro, M.D., Smyth, J., Soh, L-K., Spencer, B.D., Spielman, S.E., Wikle, C.K., Vilhuber, L. (2019) Effects of a Government-Academic Partnership: Has the NSF-Census Bureau Research Network Helped Secure the Future of the Federal Statistical System? Journal of Survey Statistics and Methodology, 7(4), 589-619.
